Hi, local Mcritchie and I'm here to talk about my work on convex relaxations for learning kernels for variance of normal.
Scott's this is joint work with Vikas Singh, Jimming Pang and Chris Hendricks.
The problem we study here is how to combine a set of basis functions given some training data.
This is similar in a sense to the MCL problem.
However, in this paper we study it from the perspective of normalized cuts and similar ratio functionals.
We argue that instead of solving a gradient descent in the space of eigenvectors, which is the common strategy for this problem, it is a helpful to study the problem in the original discrete setting.

To do so, we propose a fractional programming objective which can then lead us to a non convex QP formulation for which efficient SDP relaxations can be derived even though it is difficult to solve large scale problems using SDP.
A salient feature of our model is that the size of the problem depends only on the number of kernels and not on the number of training examples.
So this allows us to apply our model to large scale datasets.
We have done extensive experiment and analysis and we report on competitive performance on two datasets on.
